In my opinion, we need Break<D> just as we have Sequence<T>.
Breaks need to be navigable just like Sequences are.
private or private final where possible, please.
Same comment on generic variable naming as above.

Do we need this? Where?
If we need this, it must be fully incremental. If we don't need this now, I suggest we remove it for now.
Needs to be incremental.
Surely we can keep a counter instead.

This is public API, as it is exported by a public method. I suggest we treat these public types in the following way:

Interface with the user-facing stuff is in api. (Sequence)
Implementation with constructors and all the protected stuff is in impl. (SequenceImpl)
Implementations have every method public, but the classes themselves are not.

This way, we make it very clear what is or is not accessible by users, but we get to hide the implementation.
Please apply the same to Break, ConsecutiveData and any other type that actually reaches the user.

I am a bit blurry as to what we need this for. But I really do not like the fact that it is not incremental.
My view of Sequence is that is just a dumb no-op view to the underlying collection. (See the idea of a timeline I tried to explain earlier.)
Type names.

So all mutating methods are unsupported? In that case I doubt if the type is good for anything.
What's the benefit of this as opposed to a couple of static util methods?
Or a more tailored class that is not a List? It looks to me as if the List forces you to implement stuff you don't really need, obfuscating the purpose of the class.

Nice to standardize this.
Consider implementing one method with the other, so that the logic is not duplicated.

I would put the nested stream first, into its own variable. That way, this will become much better to read.
Also, the formatting of the consecutive filters and penalize doesn't seem right here. They should be on the same level.
Dtto.

The additions and removals from these bags are going to be where this code spends the most time, I think.
It will be imperative to optimize it.
I still have the idea of a timeline in my head.
Where the timeline would essentially be a list of shifts in order.
And the sequences would essentially just be a tuple of (indexFrom, indexTo), pointing to that list.
To retrieve the shifts, you then just do subList(indexFrom, indexTo), which is pretty much a no-op.
But I have no proof that it would actually be faster. (It could be simpler, though.)
It'd have to be tried.

It would seem that you do not need the join with the MinMaxContractLine.
The same could possibly be done with ifExists(...) after from(Employee.class).
This has the potential to speed up things quite a bit.

It is questionable if you even need the Employee join. You can read the employee from the ShiftAssignment directly.
Another potential perf improvement.
Please take care to maintain proper indentation, the filtrers and penalties ought to start at the same column. This is just one instance of multiple of this problem.
Please remove the use of BiTuple here.

Instead of the many joins and the mapping, wouldn't it be better to just group by employee+shiftType on the shift assignment directly?
Quad joins will be very expensive on their own, we should try to avoid them as much as possible.
